Experimental determination of optical properties for black silicon Pyramid textured c-Si can effectively be modelled by a relatively simple ray tracing approach [1] based on geometrical optics, due to their simple morphology and typical lateral size of several microns, i.e. much larger than the wavelength of interest (roughly comprised between 280 and 1200 nm for silicon solar cells). However, this simple model fails to describe the optical properties of black silicon: indeed, the lateral size of such surfaces lies in the same range as the wavelength of incoming light. Other models (based on electromagnetic theory), such as the rigorous coupled wave analysis (RCWA) [6], or the finite-difference time domain (FDTD) method [7-8] have been used to effectively simulate the optical behavior of black silicon structures. Yet, these methods require high computational resources and their results are usually only concordant with experiments in a limited range of wavelengths, especially due to simplifications on the modelled structures (e.g. periodicity, ideal geometrical shapes [9]). In order to compare the optical properties of black silicon structures with pyramidal texturing, we propose a much simpler approach where the optical properties of black silicon surfaces are evaluated experimentally (measurement of Rtot, Ttot and Atot by spectrophotometry with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 9501) and used as inputs for a solar cell simulation using Quokka2 software [4]. With Quokka2, the optical properties of simulated structures are defined by two parameters: the transmittance TSi of light into the silicon bulk, and the path length enhancement factor Z (both being wavelength-dependent). Limitations of the study Using simple optical characterizations (at an early stage of the development of the nanotexturing) and solar cell simulation with Quokka2, this study has shown that nanotexturing would be susceptible to compete with typical chemical texturing on the way towards thinner n-PERT solar cell. Indeed, nanotexturing is shown compatible with high efficiencies, as the photogenerated current gain due to light-trapping becomes preponderant when the absorber thickness is reduced [12]. However, in order to surpass conventional chemical texturing in terms of efficiency, the collection of photogenerated carriers from UV light has to be ensured. To this aim, several conditions have to be fulfilled and have not been taken into account in the present study. In particular, depending on the emitter doping level and formation [13], the losses in external quantum efficiency in the UV region are underestimated, and a careful study of the recombination level in the emitter will have to be conducted. A better prediction of the blue response of nanotextured solar cells would require additional EQE measurements. Moreover, a large part of the UV light might be lost due to the encapsulant material absorption in the module [14]. In the near-IR region where silicon becomes semi-transparent, the uncertainty on the extrapolation of the transmittance (Equation 1) showed to have little influence on the simulated solar cell performances. Regarding the light path enhancement factor, the very good agreement (adjusted coefficient of determination superior to 0.999) between the measured absorptance and the model shows the relevance of the model from McIntosh and Baker-Finch (Equation 2 and 3) even in the case of nanostructured surfaces. This stems in particular from the absence of photonic effects due to the pseudo-random distribution of the nanostructures. Furthermore, simulations were performed only under a front illumination without albedo reflection as Quokka2 does not include both side illuminations on same time. Thus no bifaciality gain was studied in this work. Finally, results of this work should be considered as an optical perspective. Indeed issues of surface passivation have not been taken into account into this study, as the surface recombination velocity (SRV) has been set to an identical value (100 cm/s) for all tested structures. In experimental devices, using similar passivation schemes with different surface morphologies would produce different values of SRV, especially due to higher surface area of nanostructured silicon surfaces [15]. However, the herein implemented SRV values can be considered conservative as much lower values have been reported for ALD-Al2O3 passivated black silicon surfaces [16]. 4. Conclusion Several solar cell simulations with different combinations of front and rear texturing including black silicon were performed. Results point a potential +1%abs efficiency gain for one side front nanotexturing cell without antireflection coating layer compared to standard antireflection coatings on both sides pyramid texturing for bifacial n-PERT solar cells. Caution should be taken to average lateral size of nanostructures, because below the scaled wavelength limit (Î»/nSi) such a surface scatters no more light and thus implies light-trapping losses. Furthermore, from a process integration perspective, combining rear pyramid texturing with front nanotexturing on a solar cell does not enhance significantly Jsc to be considered at 180 Âµm thickness compared to a polish etched rear with front nanotexturing. However, such a combination affords higher light trapping and thus higher resilience of optical performances over a solar cell thickness reduction. Limitations of the study Using simple optical characterizations (at an early stage of the development of the nanotexturing) and solar cell simulation with Quokka2, this study has shown that nanotexturing would be susceptible to compete with typical chemical texturing on the way towards thinner n-PERT solar cell. Indeed, nanotexturing is shown compatible with high efficiencies, as the photogenerated current gain due to light-trapping becomes preponderant when the absorber thickness is reduced [12]. However, in order to surpass conventional chemical texturing in terms of efficiency, the collection of photogenerated carriers from UV light has to be ensured. To this aim, several conditions have to be fulfilled and have not been taken into account in the present study. In particular, depending on the emitter doping level and formation [13], the losses in external quantum efficiency in the UV region are underestimated, and a careful study of the recombination level in the emitter will have to be conducted. A better prediction of the blue response of nanotextured solar cells would require additional EQE measurements. Moreover, a large part of the UV light might be lost due to the encapsulant material absorption in the module [14]. In the near-IR region where silicon becomes semi-transparent, the uncertainty on the extrapolation of the transmittance (Equation 1) showed to have little influence on the simulated solar cell performances. Regarding the light path enhancement factor, the very good agreement (adjusted coefficient of determination superior to 0.999) between the measured absorptance and the model shows the relevance of the model from McIntosh and Baker-Finch (Equation 2 and 3) even in the case of nanostructured surfaces. This stems in particular from the absence of photonic effects due to the pseudo-random distribution of the nanostructures. Furthermore, simulations were performed only under a front illumination without albedo reflection as Quokka2 does not include both side illuminations on same time. Thus no bifaciality gain was studied in this work. Finally, results of this work should be considered as an optical perspective. Indeed issues of surface passivation have not been taken into account into this study, as the surface recombination velocity (SRV) has been set to an identical value (100 cm/s) for all tested structures. In experimental devices, using similar passivation schemes with different surface morphologies would produce different values of SRV, especially due to higher surface area of nanostructured silicon surfaces [15]. However, the herein implemented SRV values can be considered conservative as much lower values have been reported for ALD-Al2O3 passivated black silicon surfaces [16]. 4.
